articles.headline: Digital Age Is Slow to Arrive in Rural America
articles.snippet: Only 60 percent of rural American households use broadband Internet service, a government report says.
articles.abstract: Only 60 percent of rural American households use broadband Internet service, a government report says.
articles.lead_paragraph: COFFEEVILLE, Ala.  After a couple of days in this part of rural Alabama, it is hard to complain about a dropped iPhone call or a Cee Lo video that takes a few seconds too long to load.

articles.headline: Skipping Rote Memorization in Indian Schools
articles.snippet: A project is trying to change how students are taught and tested in a country where rote memorization is the norm.
articles.abstract: A project is trying to change how students are taught and tested in a country where rote memorization is the norm.
articles.lead_paragraph: PANTNAGAR, India  The Nagla elementary school in this north Indian town looks like many other rundown government schools. Sweater-clad children sit on burlap sheets laid in rows on cold concrete floors. Lunch is prepared out back on a fire of burning twigs and branches.

articles.headline: Apple Is Weighing a Cheaper iPhone
articles.snippet: To broaden the appeal of the iPhone, Apple has been exploring ways to make the popular device less expensive.
articles.abstract: To broaden the appeal of the iPhone, Apple has been exploring ways to make the popular device less expensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple has been exploring ways to broaden the appeal of the iPhone by making the popular device less expensive and allowing users to control it with voice commands.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Nick Bilton

articles.headline: Illinois Pension Bonds to Test Investors’ Faith
articles.snippet: The state hopes to sell $3.7 billion of bonds to make this year’s contribution to its teetering pension fund, adding to its already heavy debt load.
articles.abstract: The state hopes to sell $3.7 billion of bonds to make this year’s contribution to its teetering pension fund, adding to its already heavy debt load.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first time Illinois tried to bail out its teetering pension fund by borrowing billions of dollars, it ended in disaster.
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Michael Cooper

articles.headline: Looks Like Banks Lose on Risk Plea
articles.snippet: To avoid reckless mortgage-making, banks under Dodd-Frank have to have some “skin in the game” of securitization. Their efforts to avoid retaining some risk appear to be failing.
articles.abstract: To avoid reckless mortgage-making, banks under Dodd-Frank have to have some “skin in the game” of securitization. Their efforts to avoid retaining some risk appear to be failing.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the mortgage securitization market collapsed amid a flood of defaults and foreclosures  many of them on loans that should not have been made  the cry arose for lenders to have “skin in the game.” To properly align incentives, the argument went, those who make loans must suffer if the loan goes bad.

articles.headline: Egyptians Say Military Discourages an Open Economy
articles.snippet: Former government officials, economists and business groups say the military is protecting its economic privileges and discouraging reform.
articles.abstract: Former government officials, economists and business groups say the military is protecting its economic privileges and discouraging reform.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  The Egyptian military defends the country, but it also runs day care centers and beach resorts. Its divisions make television sets, jeeps, washing machines, wooden furniture and olive oil, as well as bottled water under a brand reportedly named after a general’s daughter, Safi.

articles.headline: China’s Intimidation of Dissidents Said to Persist After Prison
articles.snippet: Security officials appear to be expanding the use of home confinement, abductions and in some cases torture.
articles.abstract: Security officials appear to be expanding the use of home confinement, abductions and in some cases torture.
articles.lead_paragraph: DONGSHIGU, China  Chen Guangcheng is officially a free man, but it is hard to imagine a life more constrained. One of the country’s most prominent rights defenders, Mr. Chen is confined to his home 24 hours a day by security agents and hired peasant men armed with sticks, bricks and walkie-talkies. Visitors who try to see him are physically repulsed and sometimes beaten. Blinding floodlights illuminate his stone farmhouse at night.
articles.byline: By Andrew Jacobs and Jonathan Ansfield

articles.headline: Clashes in Libya Worsen as Army Crushes Dissent
articles.snippet: As in Bahrain and Iran, the police and army in Libya have moved quickly to crush the escalating unrest.
articles.abstract: As in Bahrain and Iran, the police and army in Libya have moved quickly to crush the escalating unrest.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  Thousands gathered Friday for a third day of violent demonstrations in Benghazi, Libya’s second-largest city, in an unprecedented challenge to the mercurial 41-year reign of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. Human rights groups said 24 people had been killed across the North African country, though activists say the count may be far higher.

articles.headline: Local, Organic Milk: Nice Idea, but Try Making a Profit
articles.snippet: A dairy co-operative in coastal Maine that produces slow-pasteurized organic milk is struggling to find enough customers to stay in business.
articles.abstract: A dairy co-operative in coastal Maine that produces slow-pasteurized organic milk is struggling to find enough customers to stay in business.
articles.lead_paragraph: EDMUNDS, Me.  Perched on the rocky coast of far eastern Maine, the farm owned by Aaron Bell and Carly DelSignore is stunning, both in its views of Cobscook Bay and in the distance that the milk they sell must travel to get on the shelves.
